title: Herschel McCoy
text:
Herschel McCoy (August 6, 1912 – February 3, 1956) was an American motion picture <a href="costume%20designer">costume designer</a> with credits on more than 150 feature films from 1936 to 1955. He was nominated twice for the <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Costume%20Design">Academy Award for Best Costume Design</a>.
McCoy's early efforts were largely focused on <a href="B%20movies">B movies</a>, such as several entries in the <a href="Charlie%20Chan">Charlie Chan</a> and <a href="Mr.%20Moto">Mr. Moto</a> canons. He had just graduated to major studio productions like an uncredited assist on "<a href="Joan%20of%20Arc%20%281948%20film%29">Joan of Arc</a>" (1948), "<a href="Quo%20Vadis%20%281951%20film%29">Quo Vadis</a>" (1951), and "<a href="Dream%20Wife">Dream Wife</a>" (1953) when he died suddenly in 1956 at the age of 43. For the last two films, McCoy was nominated for the <a href="Academy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Costume%20Design">Academy Award for Best Costume Design</a>.
McCoy's drawings for twenty-two of his designs are in the collection of the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20County%20Museum%20of%20Art">Los Angeles County Museum of Art</a>.
